title: About Me
text: Hi! My name is Joy and I am an all-around curious and creative person who loves exploring new ideas, solving problems, and making things. Coding is my passion, besides web design. This started out as a project for my communications class, shout out to you Professor O’Donnell, and I wanted to continue with it! I am currently studying compuuter science with a concentration in Artificial Intelligence at the University of Pennsylvania and in my free time, I like to crochet amigurumis.

title: Professor G’s Great GPT
text:
Based on his book with the same title, Prof G fed ChatGPT every problem and lesson plan covered for the semester. For those taking MATH 1400 or MATH 1410, Calc Star Green/Blue has proven incredibly useful and helpful.



Calculus Blue, the book


The commands available include /intro, /ex, /score, and /test. Calling them is fairly intuitive with most of their names describing their purposes, while some like /score may not be easily understood. /score is when the user wants their test to be rated by an emoji or /go for a week’s specific material.



Calc Star Blue, the GPT


However as of September 14, when prompted to give information about Week Four, it limits itself to four of the nine learning objectives. It decided Week 4 was “all about determinants as volume-scaling factors”. When asked about the rest of the learning objectives, it corrected itself and revised the response it gave to my original question for help. It now covered topics like orthogonal and orthonormal bases, linear transformations as matrices, and minor expansion in computing determinants.



Revision of response


Nonetheless, Prof G has created something any student can use to learn single or multi-variable calculus. Need help on a topic or want to get some questions to gauge your understanding? Calcstar Blue and Calcstar Green have got you covered!

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text: Colorectal cancer starts in the large intestine and the longer it is left untreated, the more in spreads until it becomes impossible to treat. Unfortunately, by the time symptoms are apparent it is too late for treatements like radiation or surgery. Still, it’s been hypothesized and proposed in making use of machine learning to classify and identify cancerous tissue.

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text: Colorectal cancer starts in the large intestine and the longer it is left untreated, the more in spreads until it becomes impossible to treat. Unfortunately, by the time symptoms are apparent it is too late for treatements like radiation or surgery. Still, it’s been hypothesized and proposed in making use of machine learning to classify and identify cancerous tissue.

title: Can AI reduce the mortality rate of colorectal cancer?
text:
Machine Learning and Diagnosing
In the summer of 2024, I and several others worked to figure out if it was possible. Using the data from the University of Jyväskylä, we trained an AI model to determine whether or not the tissue contained signs of cancer.
 
The first round of sequencing and feature extraction resulted in an accuracy of about 0.619, or 61.9%. To really increase the power and accuracy, we sought to augment the pictures to “create” more data as we did not have access to any other data. The final method we used was transfer learning where the predictions output layer was changed to 8, everything but the output layer was frozen, and images were of size 150 pixels x 150 pixels.
 
A confusion matrix, a table used in machine learning to evaluate the performance of a classification model provides a more detailed insight into a model’s peformance. We had produced two confusion matrixes, one with the 61.9% as stated above and the new one, after transfer learning, was 84.4%. The accuracy in predicting eight categories of colorectal tissue grew tremendously, and this AI is capable of being integrated with other models.
 | 
However, there are pitfalls and issues with this way of testing and researching. For one, it creates biases in recognition as, without knowing for certain who the samples were taken from, the data is limited to one group. But different races and genders have symptoms specific to their group, and in the age where AI does often discriminate based on who trains them, there is a lot of room for error. In addition, there is already a distrust and dislike for AI seeping into every corners of the world, especially when it concerns the wellbeing of others and themselves. Relying on any AI to accurately determine and diagnose the cause is and will always be incredibly dangerous without further confirmation from a human’s eye.
For further interest: The University of Jyväskylä and our in-depth examination Precision Medicine in Colorectal Cancer

title: A necessary purchase don’t you think?
text: In this day and age, pets are akin to a second version of a child, a furbaby if you will. And because they are like a kid, they have the same needs as well, if not more. And one of the biggest things to worry about is if Pinkie, Sally, Choco, Toby, Princess Destroyer III, or the small chihuahua in the dog park is actually entertained.

title: A necessary purchase don’t you think?
text:
Introducing the Bounce Buddy:

The Interactive Treat-Dispensing Ball That Keeps Your Dog Entertained for Hours

title: Living With My Book, Part 1
text:
Written as a narrative explanation of the mathematics that has brought us machine learning (ML) and the ongoing explosion of artificial intelligence (AI), Ananthaswamy gives us insight on the capabilities and limitations that come with such technology. ML systems are making what are essentially life-altering decisions for us, like determining whether or not a tumor is benign, deciding if someone gets bail, or approving mortgages. They even seep into academic areas now with discoveries in chemistry, biology, extrasolar planets, and even quantum systems. But one thing to note, though, is that this was all before large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT became popular!



Ananthaswamy’s “Why Machines Learn”


This technology is based on relatively simple mathematical ideas, some of which go back centuries like linear algebra and calculus. It took the birth and advancement of computer science, and the use of 1990s computer chips designed for video games, to create an interest in the AI that we see today. And as Ananthaswamy puts it, “We are living through a revolution in machine learning-powered AI that shows no signs of slowing down”.

title: Panera’s Mac and Cheese
text:
First up, a popular chain that began in 1987 as St. Louis Bread Company, a humble community bakery founded with a sourdough starter from San Francisco and a dream of putting a loaf of bread in every arm. Now, it operates as both Panera Bread® or Saint Louis Bread Co St. Louis Bread Company in 48 states, the District of Columbia and Canada!



Panera's Mac and Cheese Bread Bowl


A fan favorite across the board (save for the people who are lactose intolerant). One of my favorite meals to eat when at Panera Bread and overall a ten across the board. Not only does it come with a great vehicle for the sauce, but the taste is phenomenal. In addition, the baguettes they make are impeccable and very delicious. The closest Panera Bread for UPenn students is located at 200 South 40th St, Philadelphia, PA 19104 across from the Acme.

title: AI in replicating human made designs and patterns
text:
To test them, I wanted to explore their expertise on crocheting! Crocheting is defined as the “process of creating textiles by using a crochet hook to interlock loops of yarn, thread, or strands of other materials” and is derived from the French word ‘crochet’ meaning hook. There are many techniques and steps to follow before a project, or design, can come to fruition. But the question still stands, can ChatGPT, or any chatbot really, give an answer that makes something decent? Chatbots are known to give information that needs to be double checked in some way, shape, or form before trusting it completely. So, what better way to test a chatbot’s correctness than to make a decoration just in time for Halloween!



Storyland Amis Black Kitty Cat


I gave openAI’s ChatGPT a single task, “give me a set of instructions to crochet a small black cat plushie for my witch costume”. It produced this:

text:

title: AI in replicating human made designs and patterns
section: 🧶 Crochet Pattern: Mini Black Cat Plushie
text:
🧶 Crochet Pattern: Mini Black Cat Plushie
Skill level: Advanced beginner (basic stitches, working in the round) Yarn: Black worsted-weight Hook: 3.5–4 mm (E–G) Other: Safety eyes (6–8 mm) or felt, stuffing, yarn needle, pink yarn/embroidery thread for nose, optional pipe cleaner for tail stiffness

Abbreviations

MR = Magic Ring
sc = single crochet
inc = increase (2 sc in one stitch)
dec = decrease (sc 2 stitches together)
st(s) = stitch(es)
FO = fasten off
Body (worked in round, stuffed as you go)
MR, 6 sc (6)
inc around (12)
(sc, inc) around (18)
(2 sc, inc) around (24)
5–10. sc around (24)
(2 sc, dec) around (18)
(sc, dec) around (12)
dec around (6)
FO, sew closed.



Head

MR, 6 sc (6)
inc around (12)
(sc, inc) around (18)
(2 sc, inc) around (24)
5–9. sc around (24)
(2 sc, dec) around (18)
(sc, dec) around (12)
Add safety eyes between rows 6–7, about 5 stitches apart.
dec around (6)
FO, sew closed.
Ears (make 2)
MR, 4 sc (4)
(sc, inc) twice (6)
sc around (6)
FO, leave tail for sewing.



Tail

MR, 6 sc (6)
2–10. sc around (6)
Stuff lightly or slide in pipe cleaner.
FO, sew closed.



Legs (make 4)

MR, 6 sc (6)
(sc, inc) around (9)
3–5. sc around (9)
FO, stuff lightly.



Assembly
Sew head to body.  Attach ears on top of head. Sew legs to bottom sides of body. Attach tail to back. Embroider a tiny pink triangle nose + whiskers with white thread (optional).


🎀 Optional Witchy Upgrades
Tiny felt witch hat glued on top. Purple ribbon collar with a little bell. Glow-in-the-dark yarn for eyes if you’re extra spooky.

title: AI in replicating human made designs and patterns
text:

To compare, I created another small black cat plushie from Storyland Amis. The results from both direction sets can be seen here:

title: Across the Quad lies a red food cart
Across the Quad lies a red food cart
section: Rahim Khan and the  red cart
text:
Rahim Khan and the  red cart 
Known for his food and cheerful disposition, Rahim has been feeding students and Philadelphians alike for quite some time now. Located across the Quad on 37th and Spruce, he serves up plates piled high with rice, several kinds meats — ranging from chicken to fish, a nice side of veggies, and a choice between white sauce, red sauce, or both!



The $8 Chicken Platter


A further look into his menu shows a wide range of meals students can get. The portion size is massive, especially for students who are on a tight budget and have to make every dollar last. And, by doing a little bit of food math, one eight dollar plate of chicken over rice can last two meals so you’re really only paying about $4!

Rice Platters

$8

$8

$9

$8

$9


Fish Salad
$9


Falafel Salad
$8



The food scene and denizens of Philadelphia rely on food trucks like Rahim’s  Red Cart  across the Quad. But unfortunately, many have been pushed out by universities and policies alike. Still, I, like many others, feel incredibly lucky that carts like Kim’s Oriental Foods, Bui’s Lunch Truck, and the one run by an elderly couple outside of David’s Rittenhouse Laboratory are here to keep us fed and happy.
Read more here and learn about his journey as Rahim the Dream.
